title: From Occident to Orient.
author: Smith, William Alexander.
snippet: It is sundown as we enter the North River; too late to pass the customs' and doctor's inspection, so our vessel comes to a halt opposite the Statue of Liberty and waits for the morning.

title: From Occident to Orient.
author: Smith, William Alexander.
snippet: The steamship arrived at her dock, pier 43, North River, last evening, with passengers, crew and cargo safe and sound, although those on board had a pretty lively experience and one a good many do not care to repeat.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: I am less than fifty years of age, but have a perfect recollection when we had no steamboats on any of our rivers; a vivid one of the discomforts consequent upon travelling in sailing packets on the Delaware and North River, as well as some experience of the poling and warping system on the western waters.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: The scenery, in itself, is not superior to our own ; it has often been compared to that of the North River ; rest assured this does not surpass much that you and I have always admired on the Hudson.

title: A knight templar abroad;
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: As we sailed majestically down the North River,

title: A knight templar abroad;
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: When the gallant ship swung around in the North River, and straightened herself out for another wrestle with Father Neptune, there was a perfect  crush of humanity upon the pier, waving their hats and handkerchiefs, and shouting their last farewells.

title: A holiday tour in Europe.
author: Cook, Joel
snippet: A brief delay at quarantine whilst the port physician satisfied  himself that sea-sickness had been the only epidemic on board (his inspection being chiefly made through the bottom of a tumbler kindly loaned him by the ship's doctor, who did likewise) was followed by a sail through the Narrows to the pier on North River.

title: Journal of a Residence in Scotland, and Tour through England, France, Germany, Switzerland and Italy. With a memoir of the author and extracts from his religious papers. ... Compiled by I. MacLellan, Jr
author: Maclellan, Henry B.
snippet: —Yesterday we went upthe North River, as far as West Point.

title: Journal of a Residence in Scotland, and Tour through England, France, Germany, Switzerland and Italy. With a memoir of the author and extracts from his religious papers. ... Compiled by I. MacLellan, Jr
author: Maclellan, Henry B.
snippet: It commenceswith a brief notice of a trip up the North River, writtenon the day he sailed from New York ; and is followed bya description of the voyage to Liverpool ; from which wehave extracted, what seemed to us to be the most interesting passages.

title: Sparks from a Locomotive; or Life and Liberty in Europe. By the author of “Belle Brittan's Letters.” [The dedication signed, H. F., i.e. H. Fuller.]
author: F., H.
snippet: canal in Symington's boat, launched the Clennonton the North River, all the old fogies of the cityassembled at the Battery to witness the grandfailure, and to pronounce the oracular " I told youso !" In the year 1819, when the Savannah, a sortof mongrel, half steamer, half sailer, left NewYork for Liverpool, many were the lugubrious predictions that she would " blow up " before reachingport; and even as recently as 1838, when the GreatWestern made her first passage across the Atlantic,in spite of scientific theories and the skepticalshrugs of veteran "Salts," the practicability ofocean steam navigation could hardly be regarded asone of the established facts and "received opinions" of the world.

title: A Knight Templar abroad; or, Reminiscences of travel beyond the sea
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: As we sailed majestically down the North River,

title: A Knight Templar abroad; or, Reminiscences of travel beyond the sea
